results.headline: An Angel Rides in to Preserve a Family (and India)
results.summary_short: “Thoda Pyaar, Thoda Magic” (“A Little Love, a Little Magic”) has a buoyancy and optimism that trump the predictability of its story.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Thoda Pyaar Thoda Magic

results.headline: When an Eloquent Voice Was Stilled in Hollywood
results.summary_short: Peter Askin’s stirring documentary “Trumbo” gives you reasons to cheer but also to weep.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Trumbo

results.headline: A Whirling, Digitized Ride on a Small Celluloid Raft
results.summary_short: An eye-popper and brain-boggler, “Razzle Dazzle” is also, remarkably, a thing to stir the soul.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Razzle Dazzle: The Lost World

results.headline: The Sex and the Fury, French Aristocracy Style
results.summary_short: In “The Last Mistress,” the director Catherine Breillat’s explorations of desire are so far from the antiseptic world of most screen depictions as to seem far out.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Mistress

results.headline: In a World Left Silent, One Heart Beeps
results.summary_short: “Wall-E” breaks new ground in giving us a G-rated, computer-generated cartoon vision of our own potential extinction.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of WALL-E

results.headline: Dipping Into Many Modes
results.summary_short: “All in This Tea” is a delicious documentary about a beverage.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of All in This Tea

results.headline: One Gloomy Family
results.summary_short: In “Red Roses and Petrol,” a soused, post-funeral postmortem on a dysfunctional Dublin family, the misery seeps from the screen in cold, damp waves.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Red Roses and Petrol

results.headline: Marching Noisily Toward Late Middle Age
results.summary_short: “Elsa & Fred” is both a movie about love and a love letter to movies.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Elsa and Fred

results.headline: Cannibal Witches on the Prowl
results.summary_short: It’s not the water that menaces in “Wicked Lake,” an inept, nasty and absolutely irredeemable entry in the stale torture-porn subgenre of horror.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wicked Lake

results.headline: You Talkin’ to Me, Boys? (Bang-Bang, My Pretties)
results.summary_short: “Wanted” shows life in the killing lane with lots of zippy effects, action and exploding heads.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wanted

results.headline: For Love of the Game
results.summary_short: “Gunnin’ for That #1 Spot” is an on-the-fly record of a memorable moment in basketball history.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gunnin' for That #1 Spot

results.headline: A Gambler Goes to Sin City in Search of Atonement
results.summary_short: Set mostly in Las Vegas, “Finding Amanda” offers a vision of confused Americans losing their already shaky bearings in the world’s gaudiest honky-tonk.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Finding Amanda

results.headline: He’ll Hold His Breath Until You Call Him a Man
results.summary_short: The candy-colored “Full Grown Men” wants to be a kind of anti-“Wizard of Oz” for a culture inundated with toys and toons.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Full Grown Men

results.headline: Portrait of a Haunted Artist Who Befriended Giant Spiders
results.summary_short: This uncommonly elegant and evocative portrait of Louise Bourgeois reveals much about the haunting and haunted master while leaving intact the thing you cannot explain.
results.display_title: Louise Bourgeois: The Spider, the Mistress and the Tangerine

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Louise Bourgeois: The Spider, the Mistress and the Tangerine

results.headline: Trying to Find True Love Before the Meter Runs Out
results.summary_short: The funny, sad, offbeat, sometimes off-the-beat romance “Expired” is one of those precariously balanced movies that might fall to pieces with a different cast.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Expired

results.headline: A Prisoner of Normalcy Finds Ways to Escape
results.summary_short: At the center of “Brick Lane,” a modest film directed by Sarah Gavron, is a woman for whom modesty is not just a defining character trait but also a moral principle.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Brick Lane

results.headline: More Deadpan but Still a Bumbler
results.summary_short: “Get Smart” is made up of feeble and funny jokes, brand actors and enough special effects to give you some bang for your summertime buck.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Get Smart

results.headline: Wholesome Life Lessons for Budding Reporter
results.summary_short: “Kit Kittredge: An American Girl” appears poised to incite the kind of box-office frenzy more commonly associated with characters named Hannah and Harry.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kit Kittredge: An American Girl

results.headline: Just Say ‘Mariska Hargitay’ and Snicker
results.summary_short: “The Love Guru” is downright antifunny, an experience that makes you wonder if you will ever laugh again.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Love Guru

results.headline: A May-December Love for All Seasons
results.summary_short: “Chris & Don: A Love Story” examines a complicated and enduring relationship that raised eyebrows even in Hollywood.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chris & Don: A Love Story
